Identification_Area.title: Combined Radial Profile Index for All Bundles in the Uranus system, Earth-Based Occultation Series.

Citation_Information.author_list: French, Richard G.; McGhee-French, Colleen A.; Gordon, Mitchell K.
Citation_Information.description: Table of metadata for each radial profile in each Uranus Occultation data bundle.

Header.description: Provides the column headers, separated by commas, for the data table.

Table_Character.description: Table of metadata. Each record (row) in the table supports a single radial profile. The table supports all of the Uranus Earth based occultation data bundles provided to the PDS by Richard French, et al.

Field_Character.name: LID
Field_Character.description: LID of the radial profile product.

Field_Character.name: File Name
Field_Character.description: Name of the radial profile product XML label file.

Field_Character.name: File Specification
Field_Character.description: File path from the bundle root directory to the XML label file of the radial profile product. The concatenation of the pds: directory_path_name and file_name

Field_Character.name: Bundle LID
Field_Character.description: Lid of the bundle.

Field_Character.name: Bundle Name
Field_Character.description: Name of the bundle

Field_Character.name: Star ID
Field_Character.description: The shorthand star identifier.

Field_Character.name: Start Time UTC
Field_Character.description: The start time in UTC.

Field_Character.name: Stop Time UTC
Field_Character.description: The stop time in UTC.

Field_Character.name: Wavelength Range
Field_Character.description: The nominal wavelength range.

Field_Character.name: Target
Field_Character.description: The general target. For this project

Field_Character.name: Target
Field_Character.description: The specific target. For this project the name of the single ring; blank for profiles of the full system.

Field_Character.name: Observing System
Field_Character.description: The observing system - generally the observatory and telescope with telescope identified by aperature diameter in cm.

Field_Character.name: Instrument Name
Field_Character.description: The name of the instrument.

Field_Character.name: Occultation Type
Field_Character.description: The occultation type - "stellar" for all occultation profiles in this project.

Field_Character.name: Occultation Direction
Field_Character.description: The direction of the occultation

Field_Character.name: Ring Profile Direction
Field_Character.description: The direction of the radial profile

Field_Character.name: Planetary Occultation Flag
Field_Character.description: Flag (Y

Field_Character.name: Data Quality Score
Field_Character.description:
Indicates the overall quality of the data. Possible values are:
0 Not observable - observations at the predicted occultation event time for this ring were either not recorded (for example, the star was below the horizon) or the occultation chord did not intersect the ring.
1 High-SNR profile with sharp edges matched by square-well model fit.
2 Moderate-SNR profile with well-defined midtime from square-well model fit, but possible systematic deviations of observed ring profile from model fit.
3 Clear ring detection but less-reliable ring width and or mid-time due to noise or substantial convolution by star diameter and/or instrumental time constant.
4 Unreliable detection - some hint of a ring occultation, fitted by square-well model, but ~50% chance it is just noise.
5 No detection - Data were recorded at the expected location of a ring occultation, but no ring was observed, either because ring event was obscured by noise or (for the lambda ring) the optical depth of the ring at the observed longitude was below detectability, even if the overall SNR of the data is high.
6 Is not an indication of data quality. Indicates the product is a profile of the entire ring system based on the equator system of the planet.

Field_Character.name: Data Quality Index
Field_Character.description: Provides a more precise subjective assessment by the data provider of the quality of the observed/predicted ring occultation.

Field_Character.name: Ring Detected
Field_Character.description: Flag (Y

Field_Character.name: Ring Plane
Field_Character.description: Indicates the plane upon which parameters such as ring_radius are based.

Field_Character.name: Star Name
Field_Character.description: Provides catalog and the designation of the star in that catalog.

Field_Character.name: Fresnel scale
Field_Character.description: fresnel_scale is sqrt(lambda * D/2), where lambda is the central wavelength of the observation and D is the average distance between the observer and the occulting ring. This is an average value for the entire occultation and is a measure of the limit on the radial resolution of ring structure due to diffraction. Note that the actual overall resolution is affected as well by the projected diameter of the occulted star and the instrumental time constant, if any.

Field_Character.name: Projected Star Diameter
Field_Character.description: The projected angular diameter of the occulted star

Field_Character.name: Sigma Projected Star Diameter
Field_Character.description: The uncertainty (1-sigma) in the projected_star_diameter.

Field_Character.name: Fractional Error Star Counts
Field_Character.description: Indicates the fractional error (1-sigma) in star counts used for square-well model fit.

Field_Character.name: Time Constant Type
Field_Character.description:
time_constant_type distinguishes between three types of instrumental time constant assumed in a square-well model.
Possible values are: none - No instrumental time constant, in which case time_constant and sigma_time_constant are both zero.
single pole - A single pole filter with impulse response given by h(t) = (t/t_c^2)exp(-t/t_c) for t greater than 0, 0 for t less than 0, where t_c is the time constant. See Eq. 9 Elliot et al. (1984) Astron. J. 1587-1603.
double pole - double pole filter. was used

Field_Character.name: Time Constant
Field_Character.description: Indicates the instrumental time constant of the detector. See Eq. 9 Elliot et al. (1984) Astron. J. 1587-1603.

Field_Character.name: Sigma Time Constant
Field_Character.description: Indicates the uncertainty in the time_constant.

Field_Character.name: Minimum Wavelength
Field_Character.description: The smallest wavelength used in the observation.

Field_Character.name: Maximum Wavelength
Field_Character.description: The largest wavelength used in the observation.

Field_Character.name: Radial Resolution
Field_Character.description: Indicates the nominal radial distance over which changes in ring properties can be detected within a data product. Note: this value may be larger than the radial_sampling_interval value, because a data product can be over-sampled.

Field_Character.name: Minimum Radial Sampling Interval
Field_Character.description: Indicates the smallest radial spacing between consecutive points in a ring profile. In practice, this may be somewhat smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile may be over-sampled.

Field_Character.name: Maximum Radial Sampling Interval
Field_Character.description: Indicates the largest radial spacing between consecutive points in a ring profile. In practice, this may be somewhat smaller than the radial_resolution because a profile may be over-sampled.

Field_Character.name: Reference Time UTC
Field_Character.description: Provides a date and time in UTC format. Given in a label when time values in a table are given as elapsed seconds offset from a reference time. Unless there are compelling reasons to do otherwise, reference_time_utc should correspond to the start of a day.

Field_Character.name: Minimum Observed Event Time
Field_Character.description:
minimum_observed_event_time gives the smallest value for observed_event_time in the associated data file. It is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time.
observed_event_time indicates the instant at which photons were received at the instrument. provides a date and time in UTC format. Given in a label when time values in a table are given as elapsed seconds offset from a reference time. Generally, reference_time_utc should correspond to the start of a day.

Field_Character.name: Maximum Observed Event Time
Field_Character.description:
maximum_observed_event_time gives the largest value for observed_event_time in the associated data file. It is given in numeric seconds as an offset from the specified UTC reference time.
observed_event_time indicates the instant at which photons were received at the instrument. provides a date and time in UTC format. Given in a label when time values in a table are given as elapsed seconds offset from a reference time. Generally, reference_time_utc should correspond to the start of a day.

Field_Character.name: Observed Event Start TDB
Field_Character.description: observed_event_start_tdb indicates the value for earliest time in the described data, and is given in elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch.

Field_Character.name: Observed Event Stop TDB
Field_Character.description: observed_event_stop_tdb indicates the value for latest time in the described data, and is given in elapsed seconds since the J2000 epoch.

Field_Character.name: Ring Event Start Time UTC
Field_Character.description: Provides the UTC time corresponding to the earliest time in the described data.

Field_Character.name: Ring Event Stop Time UTC
Field_Character.description: Provides the UTC time corresponding to the latest time in the described data.

Field_Character.name: Ring Event Start TDB
Field_Character.description: Provides the 'Barycentric Dynamical Time' time corresponding to the earliest time in the described data.

Field_Character.name: Ring Event Stop TDB
Field_Character.description: Provides the 'Barycentric Dynamical Time' time corresponding to the latest time in the described data.

Field_Character.name: Earth Received Start Time UTC
Field_Character.description: The UTC time corresponding to the earliest time for the data product at which telemetry or other photons were received on Earth.

Field_Character.name: Earth Received Stop Time UTC
Field_Character.description: The UTC time corresponding to the latest time for the data product at which telemetry or other photons were received on Earth.

Field_Character.name: Minimum Ring Radius
Field_Character.description: The smallest ring radius value in the data table.

Field_Character.name: Maximum Ring Radius
Field_Character.description: The largest ring radius value in the data table.

Field_Character.name: Minimum Ring Longitude
Field_Character.description:
minimum_ring_longitude specifes one boundary for the ring longitude range in the data; normally the smallest value. However, for ranges that cross the prime meridian, the minimum ring longitude will have a value greater than the maximum ring longitude. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
ring_longitude specifies the inertial longitude of a ring feature relative to the prime meridian. In planetary ring systems, the prime meridian is the ascending node of the planet's invariable plane on the Earth's mean equator of J2000. Longitudes are measured in the direction of orbital motion along the planet's invariable plane to the ring's ascending node, and thence along the ring plane. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees. Note: The invariable plane of a planet is equivalent to its equatorial plane for every ringed planet except Neptune

Field_Character.name: Maximum Ring Longitude
Field_Character.description:
maximum_ring_longitude specifes one boundary for the ring longitude range in the data; normally the largest value. However, for ranges that cross the prime meridian, the maximum ring longitude will have a value smaller than the minimum ring longitude. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
ring_longitude specifies the inertial longitude of a ring feature relative to the prime meridian. In planetary ring systems, the prime meridian is the ascending node of the planet's invariable plane on the Earth's mean equator of J2000. Longitudes are measured in the direction of orbital motion along the planet's invariable plane to the ring's ascending node, and thence along the ring plane. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees. Note: The invariable plane of a planet is equivalent to its equatorial plane for every ringed planet except Neptune

Field_Character.name: Minimum Observed Ring Azimuth
Field_Character.description:
Specifes the smallest value for observed_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
observed_ring_azimuth is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the direction of a photon heading to the observer, and ending at the direction of a local radial vector. This angle is projected into the ring plane and measured in the prograde direction. Note that, as seen from the observer, it equals 90 degrees along the right ansa and 270 degrees along the left ansa. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.

Field_Character.name: Maximum Observed Ring Azimuth
Field_Character.description:
Specifes the largest value for observed_ring_azimuth in the data file. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.
observed_ring_azimuth is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the direction of a photon heading to the observer, and ending at the direction of a local radial vector. This angle is projected into the ring plane and measured in the prograde direction. Note that, as seen from the observer, it equals 90 degrees along the right ansa and 270 degrees along the left ansa. Values range from 0 to 360 in units of degrees.

Field_Character.name: Observed Ring Elevation
Field_Character.description: observed_ring_elevation is an angle measured at a point in the ring plane, starting from the ring plane to the direction of a photon heading to the observer. This angle is positive on the side of the ring plane defined by positive angular momentum, and negative on the opposite side. Values range from -90 to +90 in units of degrees. This angle is constant for stellar occultations, but may vary significantly during radio occultations. Note: The direction of positive angular momentum points toward the IAU-defined north side of the ring plane for Jupiter, Saturn and Neptune, but IAU-defined south side of the ring plane for Uranus.

Field_Character.name: Light Source Incidence Angle
Field_Character.description: light_source_incidence_angle is an angle measured from the local surface normal vector to the direction of a photon arriving from the light source. For rings, the normal vector is that on the same side of the rings as the light source, so values always range between 0 and 90 in units of degrees. The value is always equal to 90 - | observed_ring_elevation | This will enable users to perform database searches based on the effective ring opening angle when they are not concerned about the distinction between north-side and southside viewpoints. We have included the 'light source' prefix to the term so that this quantity is not confused with 'incidence angle', a term that is generally associated with sunlight rather than stars or radio transmitters.

Field_Character.name: Lowest Detectable Opacity
Field_Character.description:
Indicates the sensitivity of a ring occultation data set to nearly opaque rings. It specifies the rough value for the smallest normal ring opacity that can be detected in the data at the resolution provided, incorporating both statistical effects and calibration uncertainties.
-1.0 indicates the signal was too poor to allow the calculation of the value.

Field_Character.name: Highest Detectable Opacity
Field_Character.description:
Indicates the sensitivity of a ring occultation data set to nearly opaque rings. It specifies the rough value for the largest normal ring opacity that can be detected in the data at the resolution provided, incorporating both statistical effects and calibration uncertainties.
-1.0 indicates the signal was too poor to allow the calculation of the value.
